column2: They might be dried meat from some queer beast, Jim.	They might be dried meat from some queer beast, Jim.
column3: false

column2: They ain't dried fish, and they never grew on stalk or vine.
column3: They ain't dried fish, and they never grew on stalk or vine.

column2: I'm afraid of 'em.
column3: I'm afraid of 'em.

column2: Anyhow, I should n't want to eat anything that had been shut up for months with old clothes and goose pillows."
column3: Anyhow, I should n't want to eat anything that had been shut up for months with old clothes and goose pillows."

column2: She threw the package into the stove, but I bit off a corner of one of the chips I held in my hand, and chewed it tentatively.
column3: She threw the package into the stove, but I bit off a corner of one of the chips I held in my hand, and chewed it tentatively.

column2: I never forgot the strange taste; though it was many years before I knew that those little brown shavings, which the Shimerdas had brought so far and treasured so jealously, were dried mushrooms.
column3: I never forgot the strange taste; though it was many years before I knew that those little brown shavings, which the Shimerdas had brought so far and treasured so jealously, were dried mushrooms.

column2: They had been gathered, probably, in some deep Bohemian forest {~HORIZONTAL ELLIPSIS~}
column3: They had been gathered, probably, in some deep Bohemian forest {~ HORIZONTAL ELLIPSIS ~}

column2: XI
column3: XI

column2: DURING the week before Christmas, Jake was the most important person of our household, for he was to go to town and do all our Christmas shopping. But on the 21st of December, the snow began to fall.
column3: DURING the week before Christmas, Jake was the most important person of our household, for he was to go to town and do all our Christmas shopping. But on the twenty first of December, the snow began to fall.

column2: The flakes came down so thickly that from the sitting-room windows I could not see beyond the windmill--its frame looked dim and gray, unsubstantial like a shadow.
column3: The flakes came down so thickly that from the sitting room windows I could not see beyond the windmill-its frame looked dim and gray, unsubstantial like a shadow.

column2: The snow did not stop falling all day, or during the night that followed.
column3: The snow did not stop falling all day, or during the night that followed.

column2: The cold was not severe, but the storm was quiet and resistless.
column3: The cold was not severe, but the storm was quiet and resistless.

column2: The men could not go farther than the barns and corral.
column3: The men could not go farther than the barns and corral.

column2: They sat about the house most of the day as if it were Sunday; greasing their boots, mending their suspenders, plaiting whiplashes.
column3: They sat about the house most of the day as if it were Sunday; greasing their boots, mending their suspenders, plaiting whiplashes.

column2: On the morning of the 22d, grandfather announced at breakfast that it would be impossible to go to Black Hawk for Christmas purchases.
column3: On the morning of the twenty two d, grandfather announced at breakfast that it would be impossible to go to Black Hawk for Christmas purchases.

column2: Jake was sure he could get through on horseback, and bring home our things in saddle-bags; but grandfather told him the roads would be obliterated, and a newcomer in the country would be lost ten times over.
column3: Jake was sure he could get through on horseback, and bring home our things in saddle bags; but grandfather told him the roads would be obliterated, and a newcomer in the country would be lost ten times over.

column2: Anyway, he would never allow one of his horses to be put to such a strain.
column3: Anyway, he would never allow one of his horses to be put to such a strain.

column2: We decided to have a country Christmas, without any help from town.
column3: We decided to have a country Christmas, without any help from town.

column2: I had wanted to get some picture-books for Yulka and Antonia; even Yulka was able to read a little now.
column3: I had wanted to get some picture books for Yulka and Antonia; even Yulka was able to read a little now.

column2: Grandmother took me into the ice-cold storeroom, where she had some bolts of gingham and sheeting.
column3: Grandmother took me into the ice cold storeroom, where she had some bolts of gingham and sheeting.

column2: She cut squares of cotton cloth and we sewed them together into a book.
column3: She cut squares of cotton cloth and we sewed them together into a book.

column2: We bound it between pasteboards, which I covered with brilliant calico, representing scenes from a circus.
column3: We bound it between pasteboards, which I covered with brilliant calico, representing scenes from a circus.

column2: For two days I sat at the dining-room table, pasting this book full of pictures for Yulka.
column3: For two days I sat at the dining room table, pasting this book full of pictures for Yulka.

column2: We had files of those good old family magazines which used to publish colored lithographs of popular paintings, and I was allowed to use some of these.
column3: We had files of those good old family magazines which used to publish colored lithographs of popular paintings, and I was allowed to use some of these.

column2: I took "Napoleon Announcing the Divorce to Josephine" for my frontispiece.
column3: I took "Napoleon Announcing the Divorce to Josephine" for my frontispiece.

column2: On the white pages I grouped Sunday-School cards and advertising cards which I had brought from my "old country." Fuchs got out the old candle-moulds and made tallow candles.
column3: On the white pages I grouped Sunday School cards and advertising cards which I had brought from my "old country." Fuchs got out the old candle moulds and made tallow candles.

column2: Grandmother hunted up her fancy cake-cutters and baked gingerbread men and roosters, which we decorated with burnt sugar and red cinnamon drops.
column3: Grandmother hunted up her fancy cake cutters and baked gingerbread men and roosters, which we decorated with burnt sugar and red cinnamon drops.

column2: On the day before Christmas, Jake packed the things we were sending to the Shimerdas in his saddle-bags and set off on grandfather's gray gelding. When he mounted his horse at the door, I saw that he had a hatchet slung to his belt, and he gave grandmother a meaning look which told me he was planning a surprise for me.
column3: On the day before Christmas, Jake packed the things we were sending to the Shimerdas in his saddle bags and set off on grandfather's gray gelding. When he mounted his horse at the door, I saw that he had a hatchet slung to his belt, and he gave grandmother a meaning look which told me he was planning a surprise for me.

column2: That afternoon I watched long and eagerly from the sitting-room window.
column3: That afternoon I watched long and eagerly from the sitting room window.

column2: At last I saw a dark spot moving on the west hill, beside the half-buried cornfield, where the sky was taking on a coppery flush from the sun that did not quite break through.
column3: At last I saw a dark spot moving on the west hill, beside the half buried cornfield, where the sky was taking on a coppery flush from the sun that did not quite break through.

column2: I put on my cap and ran out to meet Jake.
column3: I put on my cap and ran out to meet Jake.

column2: When I got to the pond I could see that he was bringing in a little cedar tree across his pommel.
column3: When I got to the pond I could see that he was bringing in a little cedar tree across his pommel.

column2: He used to help my father cut Christmas trees for me in Virginia, and he had not forgotten how much I liked them.
column3: He used to help my father cut Christmas trees for me in Virginia, and he had not forgotten how much I liked them.

column2: By the time we had placed the cold, fresh-smelling little tree in a corner of the sitting-room, it was already Christmas Eve.
column3: By the time we had placed the cold, fresh smelling little tree in a corner of the sitting room, it was already Christmas Eve.

column2: After supper we all gathered there, and even grandfather, reading his paper by the table, looked up with friendly interest now and then.
column3: After supper we all gathered there, and even grandfather, reading his paper by the table, looked up with friendly interest now and then.

column2: The cedar was about five feet high and very shapely.
column3: The cedar was about five feet high and very shapely.

column2: We hung it with the gingerbread animals, strings of popcorn, and bits of candle which Fuchs had fitted into pasteboard sockets.
column3: We hung it with the gingerbread animals, strings of popcorn, and bits of candle which Fuchs had fitted into pasteboard sockets.

column2: Its real splendors, however, came from the most unlikely place in the world--from Otto's cowboy trunk.
column3: Its real splendors, however, came from the most unlikely place in the world-from Otto's cowboy trunk.

column2: I had never seen anything in that trunk but old boots and spurs and pistols, and a fascinating mixture of yellow leather thongs, cartridges, and shoemaker's wax.
column3: I had never seen anything in that trunk but old boots and spurs and pistols, and a fascinating mixture of yellow leather thongs, cartridges, and shoemaker's wax.

column2: From under the lining he now produced a collection of brilliantly colored paper figures, several inches high and stiff enough to stand alone.
column3: From under the lining he now produced a collection of brilliantly colored paper figures, several inches high and stiff enough to stand alone.

column2: They had been sent to him year after year, by his old mother in Austria.
column3: They had been sent to him year after year, by his old mother in Austria.

column2: There was a bleeding heart, in tufts of paper lace; there were the three kings, gorgeously appareled, and the ox and the ass and the shepherds; there was the Baby in the manger, and a group of angels, singing; there were camels and leopards, held by the black slaves of the three kings.
column3: There was a bleeding heart, in tufts of paper lace; there were the three kings, gorgeously appareled, and the ox and the ass and the shepherds; there was the Baby in the manger, and a group of angels, singing; there were camels and leopards, held by the black slaves of the three kings.

column2: Our tree became the talking tree of the fairy tale; legends and stories nestled like birds in its branches.
column3: Our tree became the talking tree of the fairy tale; legends and stories nestled like birds in its branches.

column2: Grandmother said it reminded her of the Tree of Knowledge.
column3: Grandmother said it reminded her of the Tree of Knowledge.

column2: We put sheets of cotton wool under it for a snow-field, and Jake's pocket-mirror for a frozen lake.
column3: We put sheets of cotton wool under it for a snow field, and Jake's pocket mirror for a frozen lake.

column2: I can see them now, exactly as they looked, working about the table in the lamplight: Jake with his heavy features, so rudely moulded that his face seemed, somehow, unfinished; Otto with his half-ear and the savage scar that made his upper lip curl so ferociously under his twisted mustache.
column3: I can see them now, exactly as they looked, working about the table in the lamplight: Jake with his heavy features, so rudely moulded that his face seemed, somehow, unfinished; Otto with his half ear and the savage scar that made his upper lip curl so ferociously under his twisted mustache.

column2: As I remember them, what unprotected faces they were; their very roughness and violence made them defenseless.
column3: As I remember them, what unprotected faces they were; their very roughness and violence made them defenseless.

column2: These boys had no practiced manner behind which they could retreat and hold people at a distance.
column3: These boys had no practiced manner behind which they could retreat and hold people at a distance.

column2: They had only their hard fists to batter at the world with.
column3: They had only their hard fists to batter at the world with.

column2: Otto was already one of those drifting, case-hardened laborers who never marry or have children of their own.
column3: Otto was already one of those drifting, case hardened laborers who never marry or have children of their own.

column2: Yet he was so fond of children!
column3: Yet he was so fond of children!
